[% META title = "API Documentation" description = "Comprehensive API reference for the Comserv system" roles = "normal,editor,admin,developer" category = "developer_guides" %]

Comserv API Documentation

API Overview

The Comserv API provides programmatic access to system functionality, allowing developers to:

  • Retrieve and manipulate data
  • Integrate with external systems
  • Extend platform functionality
  • Automate workflows
  • Build custom interfaces
Note: API access requires authentication and appropriate permissions. Contact your system administrator for API credentials.

Authentication

Obtaining API Credentials

  1. Navigate to Admin > Developer > API Credentials
  2. Click "Generate New API Key"
  3. Name your application and select appropriate scopes
  4. Store the generated client_id and client_secret securely

Authentication Methods

The API supports two authentication methods:

OAuth 2.0 (Recommended)

POST /api/v1/oauth/token
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

grant_type=client_credentials&
client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&
client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET

Response:

{
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "scope": "read write"
}

Use the access token in subsequent requests:

GET /api/v1/users
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...

API Key (Simple)

Include your API key in the request header:

GET /api/v1/users
X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY

Core Endpoints

Users

List Users

GET /api/v1/users

Query parameters:

  • page: Page number (default: 1)
  • limit: Results per page (default: 20, max: 100)
  • role: Filter by role (optional)
  • status: Filter by status (optional)

Response:

{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "username": "johndoe",
      "email": "john@example.com",
      "role": "editor",
      "status": "active",
      "created_at": "2023-01-15T08:30:00Z",
      "last_login": "2023-05-20T14:22:10Z"
    },
    ...
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "total_pages": 5,
    "total_count": 98
  }
}

Get User

GET /api/v1/users/{id}

Response:

{
  "id": 1,
  "username": "johndoe",
  "email": "john@example.com",
  "role": "editor",
  "status": "active",
  "created_at": "2023-01-15T08:30:00Z",
  "last_login": "2023-05-20T14:22:10Z",
  "profile": {
    "first_name": "John",
    "last_name": "Doe",
    "phone": "+1234567890",
    "bio": "System editor and content manager"
  }
}

Create User

POST /api/v1/users
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "username": "newuser",
  "email": "newuser@example.com",
  "password": "securepassword",
  "role": "normal",
  "profile": {
    "first_name": "New",
    "last_name": "User"
  }
}

Response:

{
  "id": 99,
  "username": "newuser",
  "email": "newuser@example.com",
  "role": "normal",
  "status": "active",
  "created_at": "2023-05-21T10:15:30Z"
}

Documents

List Documents

GET /api/v1/documents

Query parameters:

  • page: Page number (default: 1)
  • limit: Results per page (default: 20, max: 100)
  • category: Filter by category (optional)
  • status: Filter by status (optional)

Response:

{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "title": "Annual Report 2023",
      "category": "reports",
      "status": "published",
      "created_at": "2023-03-15T08:30:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2023-03-16T14:22:10Z",
      "author_id": 5
    },
    ...
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "total_pages": 8,
    "total_count": 156
  }
}

Error Handling

The API uses standard HTTP status codes and returns detailed error information:

{
  "error": {
    "code": "invalid_request",
    "message": "The request is missing a required parameter",
    "details": "The 'email' field is required"
  }
}

Common error codes:

  • invalid_request: Missing or invalid parameters
  • authentication_failed: Invalid credentials
  • permission_denied: Insufficient permissions
  • resource_not_found: Requested resource doesn't exist
  • rate_limit_exceeded: Too many requests

Rate Limiting

API requests are subject to rate limiting:

  • 100 requests per minute for standard API keys
  • 300 requests per minute for premium API keys

Rate limit headers are included in all responses:

X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 95
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1621612345

Webhooks

Configuring Webhooks

  1. Go to Admin > Developer > Webhooks
  2. Click "Add Webhook"
  3. Enter the destination URL
  4. Select events to subscribe to
  5. Set a secret key for signature verification

Event Types

  • user.created: New user registration
  • user.updated: User profile update
  • document.created: New document created
  • document.updated: Document updated
  • document.published: Document published

Webhook Payload

{
  "event": "document.published",
  "timestamp": "2023-05-21T15:32:10Z",
  "data": {
    "id": 42,
    "title": "New Policy Document",
    "category": "policies",
    "status": "published",
    "author_id": 5
  }
}

Signature Verification

Each webhook includes an X-Webhook-Signature header containing an HMAC-SHA256 signature. Verify this signature using your webhook secret to ensure the request is authentic.

SDKs and Libraries

Official client libraries:

  • JavaScript SDK
  • Python SDK
  • PHP SDK

API Versioning

The API uses versioning in the URL path (e.g., /api/v1/). When breaking changes are introduced, a new version will be released. We maintain backward compatibility for at least 12 months after a new version is released.

Related Documentation

  • Proxmox API Documentation - Documentation for the Proxmox VE API integration
  • Detailed API Reference - Complete reference with all endpoints and parameters

Support and Feedback

For API support:

  • Check the developer forums
  • Submit issues on GitHub
  • Contact api-support@comserv.example.com

We welcome feedback and feature requests for the API.

  • resource_not_found: Requested resource doesn't exist
  • rate_limit_exceeded: Too many requests

Rate Limiting

API requests are subject to rate limiting:

  • 100 requests per minute for standard API keys
  • 300 requests per minute for premium API keys

Rate limit headers are included in all responses:

X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 95
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1621612345

Webhooks

Configuring Webhooks

  1. Go to Admin > Developer > Webhooks
  2. Click "Add Webhook"
  3. Enter the destination URL
  4. Select events to subscribe to
  5. Set a secret key for signature verification

Event Types

  • user.created: New user registration
  • user.updated: User profile update
  • document.created: New document created
  • document.updated: Document updated
  • document.published: Document published

Webhook Payload

{
  "event": "document.published",
  "timestamp": "2023-05-21T15:32:10Z",
  "data": {
    "id": 42,
    "title": "New Policy Document",
    "category": "policies",
    "status": "published",
    "author_id": 5
  }
}

Signature Verification

Each webhook includes an X-Webhook-Signature header containing an HMAC-SHA256 signature. Verify this signature using your webhook secret to ensure the request is authentic.

SDKs and Libraries

Official client libraries:

  • JavaScript SDK
  • Python SDK
  • PHP SDK

API Versioning

The API uses versioning in the URL path (e.g., /api/v1/). When breaking changes are introduced, a new version will be released. We maintain backward compatibility for at least 12 months after a new version is released.

Related Documentation

  • Proxmox API Documentation - Documentation for the Proxmox VE API integration
  • Detailed API Reference - Complete reference with all endpoints and parameters

Support and Feedback

For API support:

  • Check the developer forums
  • Submit issues on GitHub
  • Contact api-support@comserv.example.com

We welcome feedback and feature requests for the API.

content.text: Why are you asking to run commads instead of reading the files

You're right, I apologize for the confusion. Let me focus on the existing documentation files that I've already examined.

Based on the files I've reviewed, I can see that:

1. There's a comprehensive Proxmox IP configuration documentation in `/home/shanta/PycharmProjects/comserv2/Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/ip_configuration.md`
2. There's a Proxmox commands reference in `/home/shanta/PycharmProjects/comserv2/Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/commands.md`
3. There's a Proxmox API documentation in `/home/shanta/PycharmProjects/comserv2/Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/api.md`

Since we're transitioning from .md to .tt files, I should create a corresponding .tt file for the Proxmox API documentation that includes the information about reading and modifying VM IP addresses.

Let me create a Proxmox API .tt file based on the existing api.md file, and add the requested information about reading and modifying VM IP addresses:

content.lineBasedDiff:
--- Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/api.tt +++ Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/api.tt @@ -0,0 +1,350 @@ +[% META + title = "Proxmox VE API Documentation" + description = "Overview of the Proxmox VE API endpoints used in the Comserv application" + roles = "admin,developer" + category = "infrastructure" +%] + +
+

Proxmox VE API Documentation

+ +
+

API Overview

+
+

+ This document provides an overview of the Proxmox VE (Virtual Environment) API endpoints used in the Comserv application. + The Proxmox VE API is a RESTful API that provides a wide range of endpoints for managing virtual machines, containers, nodes, storage, and more. +

+ +

Related Documentation

+
    +
  • Proxmox Command Reference - Comprehensive list of CLI commands for managing Proxmox VE
    • +
  • Proxmox IP Configuration Guide - Detailed guide for configuring IP addresses in Proxmox
    • +
+
+
+ +
+

API Base URL

+
+

The Proxmox VE API is accessible via HTTPS on port 8006:

+ + 
+https://:8006/api2/json
+
+ +

All endpoints return JSON by default unless specified otherwise.

+
+
+ +
+

Authentication

+
+

Using API Tokens (Required)

+

+ As of the latest update, our application exclusively uses API tokens for Proxmox authentication. + This eliminates the need for user login to access Proxmox functionality. API tokens don't require + CSRF tokens for write operations and provide a more secure and streamlined authentication method. +

+ + 
+Authorization: PVEAPIToken=USER@REALM!TOKENID=UUID
+
+ +

Example in our application:

+ 
+my $token = "PVEAPIToken=" . $self->{token_user} . "=" . $self->{token_value};
+$req->header('Authorization' => $token);
+
+ +

The API tokens are stored in the proxmox_credentials.json configuration file and are automatically loaded and used by the application.

+ +

Token Configuration

+
    +
  1. Log in to the Proxmox VE web interface
    2. +
  2. Navigate to Datacenter Permissions API Tokens
    3. +
  3. Create a new token for the desired user
    4. +
  4. Assign appropriate permissions (at minimum, VM.Audit for viewing VMs)
    5. +
  5. Store the token ID and value in the proxmox_credentials.json file
    6. +
+
+
+ +
+

VM IP Address Management

+
+

Reading VM IP Configuration

+

To retrieve the current IP configuration of a VM, you can use the following API endpoint:

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/config
+
+ +

This will return the complete VM configuration, including network interfaces and IP settings if configured via QEMU guest agent.

+ +

Example response (partial):

+ 
+{
+  "data": {
+    "cores": 2,
+    "memory": 2048,
+    "name": "vm-example",
+    "net0": "virtio=XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX,bridge=vmbr0",
+    "ipconfig0": "ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1"
+  }
+}
+
+ +

Reading IP Address via QEMU Guest Agent

+

If the VM has the QEMU guest agent installed and running, you can get more detailed network information:

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/agent/network-get-interfaces
+
+ +

Example response:

+ 
+{
+  "data": [
+    {
+      "name": "lo",
+      "ip-addresses": [
+        {
+          "ip-address": "127.0.0.1",
+          "prefix": 8,
+          "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
+        }
+      ]
+    },
+    {
+      "name": "eth0",
+      "ip-addresses": [
+        {
+          "ip-address": "192.168.1.100",
+          "prefix": 24,
+          "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
+        }
+      ],
+      "hardware-address": "XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX"
+    }
+  ]
+}
+
+ +

Modifying VM IP Configuration

+

To change the IP address of a VM, you can use the following API endpoint:

+ + 
+PUT /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/config
+
+ +

Parameters:

+
    +
  • ipconfig0: IP configuration for the first network interface
    • +
  • ipconfig1: IP configuration for the second network interface (if present)
    • +
  • And so on for additional interfaces...
    • +
+ +

Example request to set a static IP:

+ 
+PUT /api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config
+Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
+
+ipconfig0=ip=192.168.1.200/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+ +

Example request to set DHCP:

+ 
+PUT /api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config
+Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
+
+ipconfig0=ip=dhcp
+
+ +

Using curl to Modify IP Address

+

You can use curl to test or automate IP address changes:

+ + 
+# Set static IP for VM 100
+curl -k -X PUT \
+  "https://proxmox-host:8006/api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config" \
+  -H "Authorization: PVEAPIToken=USER@REALM!TOKENID=UUID" \
+  -d "ipconfig0=ip=192.168.1.200/24,gw=192.168.1.1"
+
+# Set DHCP for VM 100
+curl -k -X PUT \
+  "https://proxmox-host:8006/api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config" \
+  -H "Authorization: PVEAPIToken=USER@REALM!TOKENID=UUID" \
+  -d "ipconfig0=ip=dhcp"
+
+ +
+ Note: IP configuration changes via the API require the QEMU guest agent to be installed and running in the VM. The changes will be applied the next time the VM boots. +
+ +

Applying IP Changes to a Running VM

+

+ To apply IP changes to a running VM, you need to reboot the VM after changing the configuration: +

+ + 
+# First, update the IP configuration
+PUT /api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config
+Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
+
+ipconfig0=ip=192.168.1.200/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+# Then, reboot the VM to apply changes
+POST /api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/status/reboot
+
+ +

Using curl:

+ 
+# Update IP configuration
+curl -k -X PUT \
+  "https://proxmox-host:8006/api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/config" \
+  -H "Authorization: PVEAPIToken=USER@REALM!TOKENID=UUID" \
+  -d "ipconfig0=ip=192.168.1.200/24,gw=192.168.1.1"
+
+# Reboot VM to apply changes
+curl -k -X POST \
+  "https://proxmox-host:8006/api2/json/nodes/proxmox/qemu/100/status/reboot" \
+  -H "Authorization: PVEAPIToken=USER@REALM!TOKENID=UUID"
+
+
+
+ +
+

Key API Endpoints

+
+

Cluster Management

+ 
+GET /api2/json/cluster/status
+
+

Get the status of the cluster (nodes, quorum, etc.).

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/cluster/resources?type=vm
+
+

List all resources in the cluster, filtered by type (e.g., vm for VMs only).

+ +

Node Management

+ 
+GET /api2/json/nodes
+
+

List all nodes in the cluster.

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/status
+
+

Get the status of a specific node (e.g., CPU, memory usage).

+ +

Virtual Machines (QEMU/KVM)

+ 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu
+
+

List all QEMU VMs on a specific node.

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/status/current
+
+

Get the current status of a specific VM.

+ + 
+POST /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/status/start
+
+

Start a VM.

+ + 
+POST /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/status/stop
+
+

Stop a VM.

+ + 
+POST /api2/json/nodes/{node}/qemu/{vmid}/status/shutdown
+
+

Gracefully shut down a VM.

+ +

Containers (LXC)

+ 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/lxc
+
+

List all LXC containers on a specific node.

+ + 
+GET /api2/json/nodes/{node}/lxc/{vmid}/status/current
+
+

Get the current status of a container.

+
+
+ +
+

Implementation in Comserv

+
+

In our Comserv application, we primarily use the following endpoints:

+
    +
  1. /nodes - To get a list of all nodes in the cluster
    2. +
  2. /cluster/resources?type=vm - To get a list of all VMs in the cluster
    3. +
  3. /cluster/resources?type=qemu - Alternative endpoint to get QEMU VMs
    4. +
  4. /cluster/resources - To get all resources (including VMs and containers)
    5. +
  5. /nodes/{node}/qemu - To get QEMU VMs on a specific node
    6. +
  6. /nodes/{node}/lxc - To get LXC containers on a specific node
    7. +
  7. /version - To check connectivity and get Proxmox version information
    8. +
+ +

Our implementation includes fallback mechanisms to try different endpoints if the primary ones fail, ensuring robust operation even with different Proxmox configurations.

+
+
+ +
+

Error Handling

+
+

The Proxmox API returns standard HTTP status codes:

+
    +
  • 200 OK - Request successful
    • +
  • 400 Bad Request - Invalid parameters
    • +
  • 401 Unauthorized - Authentication failed
    • +
  • 403 Forbidden - Permission denied
    • +
  • 404 Not Found - Resource not found
    • +
  • 500 Internal Server Error - Server-side error
    • +
+ +

In our application, we handle these errors and provide detailed logging to help diagnose issues.

+
+
+ +
+

Further Resources

+
+
    +
  • Official Proxmox VE API Documentation
    • +
  • Access the API Viewer on your Proxmox instance: https://<your-proxmox-host>:8006/pve-docs/api-viewer/
    • +
  • Use the pvesh command-line tool on a Proxmox node (e.g., pvesh get / --output-format json) to inspect available paths dynamically
    • +
+
+
+
+ +

[% META title = "API Documentation" description = "Comprehensive API reference for the Comserv system" roles = "normal,editor,admin,developer" category = "developer_guides" %]

Comserv API Documentation

API Overview

The Comserv API provides programmatic access to system functionality, allowing developers to:

  • Retrieve and manipulate data
  • Integrate with external systems
  • Extend platform functionality
  • Automate workflows
  • Build custom interfaces
Note: API access requires authentication and appropriate permissions. Contact your system administrator for API credentials.

Authentication

Obtaining API Credentials

  1. Navigate to Admin > Developer > API Credentials
  2. Click "Generate New API Key"
  3. Name your application and select appropriate scopes
  4. Store the generated client_id and client_secret securely

Authentication Methods

The API supports two authentication methods:

OAuth 2.0 (Recommended)

POST /api/v1/oauth/token
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

grant_type=client_credentials&
client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&
client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET

Response:

{
  "access_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "scope": "read write"
}

Use the access token in subsequent requests:

GET /api/v1/users
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...

API Key (Simple)

Include your API key in the request header:

GET /api/v1/users
X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY

Core Endpoints

Users

List Users

GET /api/v1/users

Query parameters:

  • page: Page number (default: 1)
  • limit: Results per page (default: 20, max: 100)
  • role: Filter by role (optional)
  • status: Filter by status (optional)

Response:

{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "username": "johndoe",
      "email": "john@example.com",
      "role": "editor",
      "status": "active",
      "created_at": "2023-01-15T08:30:00Z",
      "last_login": "2023-05-20T14:22:10Z"
    },
    ...
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "total_pages": 5,
    "total_count": 98
  }
}

Get User

GET /api/v1/users/{id}

Response:

{
  "id": 1,
  "username": "johndoe",
  "email": "john@example.com",
  "role": "editor",
  "status": "active",
  "created_at": "2023-01-15T08:30:00Z",
  "last_login": "2023-05-20T14:22:10Z",
  "profile": {
    "first_name": "John",
    "last_name": "Doe",
    "phone": "+1234567890",
    "bio": "System editor and content manager"
  }
}

Create User

POST /api/v1/users
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "username": "newuser",
  "email": "newuser@example.com",
  "password": "securepassword",
  "role": "normal",
  "profile": {
    "first_name": "New",
    "last_name": "User"
  }
}

Response:

{
  "id": 99,
  "username": "newuser",
  "email": "newuser@example.com",
  "role": "normal",
  "status": "active",
  "created_at": "2023-05-21T10:15:30Z"
}

Documents

List Documents

GET /api/v1/documents

Query parameters:

  • page: Page number (default: 1)
  • limit: Results per page (default: 20, max: 100)
  • category: Filter by category (optional)
  • status: Filter by status (optional)

Response:

{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "title": "Annual Report 2023",
      "category": "reports",
      "status": "published",
      "created_at": "2023-03-15T08:30:00Z",
      "updated_at": "2023-03-16T14:22:10Z",
      "author_id": 5
    },
    ...
  ],
  "meta": {
    "current_page": 1,
    "total_pages": 8,
    "total_count": 156
  }
}

Error Handling

The API uses standard HTTP status codes and returns detailed error information:

{
  "error": {
    "code": "invalid_request",
    "message": "The request is missing a required parameter",
    "details": "The 'email' field is required"
  }
}

Common error codes:

  • invalid_request: Missing or invalid parameters
  • authentication_failed: Invalid credentials
  • permission_denied: Insufficient permissions
  • resource_not_found: Requested resource doesn't exist
  • rate_limit_exceeded: Too many requests

Rate Limiting

API requests are subject to rate limiting:

  • 100 requests per minute for standard API keys
  • 300 requests per minute for premium API keys

Rate limit headers are included in all responses:

X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 95
X-RateLimit-Reset: 1621612345

Webhooks

Configuring Webhooks

  1. Go to Admin > Developer > Webhooks
  2. Click "Add Webhook"
  3. Enter the destination URL
  4. Select events to subscribe to
  5. Set a secret key for signature verification

Event Types

  • user.created: New user registration
  • user.updated: User profile update
  • document.created: New document created
  • document.updated: Document updated
  • document.published: Document published

Webhook Payload

{
  "event": "document.published",
  "timestamp": "2023-05-21T15:32:10Z",
  "data": {
    "id": 42,
    "title": "New Policy Document",
    "category": "policies",
    "status": "published",
    "author_id": 5
  }
}

Signature Verification

Each webhook includes an X-Webhook-Signature header containing an HMAC-SHA256 signature. Verify this signature using your webhook secret to ensure the request is authentic.

SDKs and Libraries

Official client libraries:

  • JavaScript SDK
  • Python SDK
  • PHP SDK

API Versioning

The API uses versioning in the URL path (e.g., /api/v1/). When breaking changes are introduced, a new version will be released. We maintain backward compatibility for at least 12 months after a new version is released.

Related Documentation

  • Proxmox API Documentation - Documentation for the Proxmox VE API integration
  • Detailed API Reference - Complete reference with all endpoints and parameters

Support and Feedback

For API support:

  • Check the developer forums
  • Submit issues on GitHub
  • Contact api-support@comserv.example.com

We welcome feedback and feature requests for the API.

You're right, I made several mistakes in my approach. Let me correct this:

1. I didn't create the proper path/route in the documentation controller
2. I focused too much on the API rather than the specific commands needed to read VM settings and modify IP addresses
3. I didn't ensure the file format matches what the application expects for .tt files

Let me take a step back and approach this correctly. First, let me check the existing documentation controller to understand the routing structure:

Let me check the existing Proxmox IP configuration documentation:

content.lineBasedDiff:
--- Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/commands.tt +++ Comserv/root/Documentation/proxmox/commands.tt @@ -0,0 +1,335 @@ +[% META + title = "Proxmox VE Command Reference" + description = "Comprehensive list of command-line operations for managing Proxmox VE environments" + roles = "admin,developer" + category = "proxmox" +%] + +
+

Proxmox VE Command Reference

+ +
+

VM Configuration Management

+
+

Reading VM Configuration

+

To view the complete configuration of a VM, use the qm config command:

+ + 
+# Show VM configuration
+qm config <vmid>
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm config 100
+
+ +

This command displays all configuration parameters for the specified VM, including:

+
    +
  • CPU and memory settings
    • +
  • Disk configurations
    • +
  • Network interfaces
    • +
  • IP address settings (if configured via QEMU guest agent)
    • +
  • Boot options
    • +
  • Other VM parameters
    • +
+ +

Example output:

+ 
+boot: order=scsi0;net0
+cores: 2
+memory: 2048
+name: web-server
+net0: virtio=AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF,bridge=vmbr0
+ipconfig0: ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+scsi0: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=32G
+scsihw: virtio-scsi-pci
+
+ +

Reading VM IP Configuration

+

If the VM has the QEMU guest agent installed and running, you can get detailed network information:

+ + 
+# Get VM agent information
+qm agent <vmid> info
+
+# Get VM network interfaces
+qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm agent 100 network-get-interfaces
+
+ +

Example output:

+ 
+[
+  {
+    "name": "lo",
+    "ip-addresses": [
+      {
+        "ip-address": "127.0.0.1",
+        "prefix": 8,
+        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
+      }
+    ]
+  },
+  {
+    "name": "eth0",
+    "ip-addresses": [
+      {
+        "ip-address": "192.168.1.100",
+        "prefix": 24,
+        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
+      }
+    ],
+    "hardware-address": "AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF"
+  }
+]
+
+
+
+ +
+

Modifying VM IP Address

+
+

Setting IP Address for VMs

+

To change the IP address of a VM, use the qm set command with the --ipconfig option:

+ + 
+# Set static IP for the first network interface
+qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+ +

For multiple network interfaces, use the corresponding ipconfig parameter:

+ + 
+# Set static IP for the second network interface
+qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm set 100 --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24
+
+ +

Setting DHCP for a VM

+

To configure a VM to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

+ + 
+# Set DHCP for the first network interface
+qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp
+
+ +
+ Note: IP configuration changes require the QEMU guest agent to be installed and running in the VM. The changes will be applied the next time the VM boots. +
+ +

Applying IP Changes to a Running VM

+

After changing the IP configuration, you need to reboot the VM to apply the changes:

+ + 
+# Reboot the VM to apply changes
+qm reboot <vmid>
+
+# Example for VM with ID 100
+qm reboot 100
+
+ +

Verifying IP Configuration Changes

+

After the VM reboots, you can verify the new IP configuration:

+ + 
+# Check VM configuration
+qm config <vmid>
+
+# Check network interfaces via guest agent
+qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces
+
+
+
+ +
+

Container IP Address Management

+
+

Reading Container Configuration

+

To view the complete configuration of a container, use the pct config command:

+ + 
+# Show container configuration
+pct config <ctid>
+
+# Example for container with ID 100
+pct config 100
+
+ +

Example output:

+ 
+arch: amd64
+cores: 1
+hostname: container1
+memory: 512
+net0: name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.101/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+rootfs: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=8G
+
+ +

Modifying Container IP Address

+

To change the IP address of an existing container:

+ + 
+# Change to static IP
+pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+# Example for container with ID 101
+pct set 101 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+ +

Setting DHCP for a Container

+

To configure a container to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

+ + 
+# Change to DHCP
+pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp
+
+# Example for container with ID 100
+pct set 100 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp
+
+ +

Applying IP Changes to a Container

+

After changing the IP configuration, you need to restart the container to apply the changes:

+ + 
+# Apply changes by restarting the container
+pct restart <ctid>
+
+# Example for container with ID 101
+pct restart 101
+
+ +

Verifying Container IP Configuration

+

After the container restarts, you can verify the new IP configuration:

+ + 
+# Check container configuration
+pct config <ctid>
+
+# Enter the container to check network configuration
+pct enter <ctid>
+
+# Inside the container, check IP configuration
+ip addr show
+
+
+
+ +
+

Advanced IP Configuration

+
+

Adding Multiple Network Interfaces

+

For VMs with multiple network interfaces:

+ + 
+# Add a second network interface to a VM
+qm set <vmid> --net1 virtio,bridge=vmbr0
+
+# Configure IP for the second interface
+qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24
+
+ +

For containers with multiple network interfaces:

+ + 
+# Add a second network interface to a container
+pct set <ctid> --net1 name=eth1,bridge=vmbr1,ip=10.10.10.101/24
+
+# Add a third network interface without IP (to be configured inside the container)
+pct set <ctid> --net2 name=eth2,bridge=vmbr0,ip=manual
+
+ +

Using Cloud-Init for VM IP Configuration

+

For VMs created from Cloud-Init templates, you can set the IP address using Cloud-Init:

+ + 
+# Set Cloud-Init IP configuration
+qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
+
+# Set Cloud-Init DNS servers
+qm set <vmid> --nameserver 8.8.8.8
+
+# Set Cloud-Init search domain
+qm set <vmid> --searchdomain example.com
+
+
+
+ +
+

Troubleshooting IP Configuration

+
+

Common Issues and Solutions

+ +

VM IP Configuration Not Applied

+
    +
  • Ensure the QEMU guest agent is installed and running in the VM
    • +
  • Verify the VM has been rebooted after configuration changes
    • +
  • Check that the network interface exists in the VM
    • +
+ + 
+# Check if guest agent is enabled in VM configuration
+qm config <vmid> | grep agent
+
+# Enable guest agent if not already enabled
+qm set <vmid> --agent enabled=1
+
+# Inside the VM (for Debian/Ubuntu)
+apt update
+apt install qemu-guest-agent
+systemctl enable qemu-guest-agent
+systemctl start qemu-guest-agent
+
+ +

Container IP Configuration Not Applied

+
    +
  • Ensure the container has been restarted after configuration changes
    • +
  • Verify the network interface exists in the container
    • +
  • Check that the bridge interface exists on the host
    • +
+ + 
+# Check bridge interfaces on the host
+ip addr show | grep vmbr
+
+# Check container network configuration
+pct config <ctid> | grep net
+
+# Restart container to apply changes
+pct restart <ctid>
+
+
+
+
+ +

currentFile.content:
[% META title = "Proxmox VE Command Reference" description = "Comprehensive list of command-line operations for managing Proxmox VE environments" roles = "admin,developer" category = "proxmox" %]

Proxmox VE Command Reference

VM Configuration Management

Reading VM Configuration

To view the complete configuration of a VM, use the qm config command:

# Show VM configuration
qm config <vmid>

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm config 100

This command displays all configuration parameters for the specified VM, including:

  • CPU and memory settings
  • Disk configurations
  • Network interfaces
  • IP address settings (if configured via QEMU guest agent)
  • Boot options
  • Other VM parameters

Example output:

boot: order=scsi0;net0
cores: 2
memory: 2048
name: web-server
net0: virtio=AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF,bridge=vmbr0
ipconfig0: ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
scsi0: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=32G
scsihw: virtio-scsi-pci

Reading VM IP Configuration

If the VM has the QEMU guest agent installed and running, you can get detailed network information:

# Get VM agent information
qm agent <vmid> info

# Get VM network interfaces
qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm agent 100 network-get-interfaces

Example output:

[
  {
    "name": "lo",
    "ip-addresses": [
      {
        "ip-address": "127.0.0.1",
        "prefix": 8,
        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "name": "eth0",
    "ip-addresses": [
      {
        "ip-address": "192.168.1.100",
        "prefix": 24,
        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
      }
    ],
    "hardware-address": "AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF"
  }
]

Modifying VM IP Address

Setting IP Address for VMs

To change the IP address of a VM, use the qm set command with the --ipconfig option:

# Set static IP for the first network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

For multiple network interfaces, use the corresponding ipconfig parameter:

# Set static IP for the second network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

Setting DHCP for a VM

To configure a VM to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

# Set DHCP for the first network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp
Note: IP configuration changes require the QEMU guest agent to be installed and running in the VM. The changes will be applied the next time the VM boots.

Applying IP Changes to a Running VM

After changing the IP configuration, you need to reboot the VM to apply the changes:

# Reboot the VM to apply changes
qm reboot <vmid>

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm reboot 100

Verifying IP Configuration Changes

After the VM reboots, you can verify the new IP configuration:

# Check VM configuration
qm config <vmid>

# Check network interfaces via guest agent
qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces

Container IP Address Management

Reading Container Configuration

To view the complete configuration of a container, use the pct config command:

# Show container configuration
pct config <ctid>

# Example for container with ID 100
pct config 100

Example output:

arch: amd64
cores: 1
hostname: container1
memory: 512
net0: name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.101/24,gw=192.168.1.1
rootfs: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=8G

Modifying Container IP Address

To change the IP address of an existing container:

# Change to static IP
pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Example for container with ID 101
pct set 101 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1

Setting DHCP for a Container

To configure a container to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

# Change to DHCP
pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp

# Example for container with ID 100
pct set 100 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp

Applying IP Changes to a Container

After changing the IP configuration, you need to restart the container to apply the changes:

# Apply changes by restarting the container
pct restart <ctid>

# Example for container with ID 101
pct restart 101

Verifying Container IP Configuration

After the container restarts, you can verify the new IP configuration:

# Check container configuration
pct config <ctid>

# Enter the container to check network configuration
pct enter <ctid>

# Inside the container, check IP configuration
ip addr show

Advanced IP Configuration

Adding Multiple Network Interfaces

For VMs with multiple network interfaces:

# Add a second network interface to a VM
qm set <vmid> --net1 virtio,bridge=vmbr0

# Configure IP for the second interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

For containers with multiple network interfaces:

# Add a second network interface to a container
pct set <ctid> --net1 name=eth1,bridge=vmbr1,ip=10.10.10.101/24

# Add a third network interface without IP (to be configured inside the container)
pct set <ctid> --net2 name=eth2,bridge=vmbr0,ip=manual

Using Cloud-Init for VM IP Configuration

For VMs created from Cloud-Init templates, you can set the IP address using Cloud-Init:

# Set Cloud-Init IP configuration
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Set Cloud-Init DNS servers
qm set <vmid> --nameserver 8.8.8.8

# Set Cloud-Init search domain
qm set <vmid> --searchdomain example.com

Troubleshooting IP Configuration

Common Issues and Solutions

VM IP Configuration Not Applied

  • Ensure the QEMU guest agent is installed and running in the VM
  • Verify the VM has been rebooted after configuration changes
  • Check that the network interface exists in the VM
# Check if guest agent is enabled in VM configuration
qm config <vmid> | grep agent

# Enable guest agent if not already enabled
qm set <vmid> --agent enabled=1

# Inside the VM (for Debian/Ubuntu)
apt update
apt install qemu-guest-agent
systemctl enable qemu-guest-agent
systemctl start qemu-guest-agent

Container IP Configuration Not Applied

  • Ensure the container has been restarted after configuration changes
  • Verify the network interface exists in the container
  • Check that the bridge interface exists on the host
# Check bridge interfaces on the host
ip addr show | grep vmbr

# Check container network configuration
pct config <ctid> | grep net

# Restart container to apply changes
pct restart <ctid>

[% META title = "Proxmox VE Command Reference" description = "Comprehensive list of command-line operations for managing Proxmox VE environments" roles = "admin,developer" category = "proxmox" %]

Proxmox VE Command Reference

VM Configuration Management

Reading VM Configuration

To view the complete configuration of a VM, use the qm config command:

# Show VM configuration
qm config <vmid>

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm config 100

This command displays all configuration parameters for the specified VM, including:

  • CPU and memory settings
  • Disk configurations
  • Network interfaces
  • IP address settings (if configured via QEMU guest agent)
  • Boot options
  • Other VM parameters

Example output:

boot: order=scsi0;net0
cores: 2
memory: 2048
name: web-server
net0: virtio=AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF,bridge=vmbr0
ipconfig0: ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1
scsi0: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=32G
scsihw: virtio-scsi-pci

Reading VM IP Configuration

If the VM has the QEMU guest agent installed and running, you can get detailed network information:

# Get VM agent information
qm agent <vmid> info

# Get VM network interfaces
qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm agent 100 network-get-interfaces

Example output:

[
  {
    "name": "lo",
    "ip-addresses": [
      {
        "ip-address": "127.0.0.1",
        "prefix": 8,
        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "name": "eth0",
    "ip-addresses": [
      {
        "ip-address": "192.168.1.100",
        "prefix": 24,
        "ip-address-type": "ipv4"
      }
    ],
    "hardware-address": "AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF"
  }
]

Modifying VM IP Address

Setting IP Address for VMs

To change the IP address of a VM, use the qm set command with the --ipconfig option:

# Set static IP for the first network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

For multiple network interfaces, use the corresponding ipconfig parameter:

# Set static IP for the second network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

Setting DHCP for a VM

To configure a VM to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

# Set DHCP for the first network interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm set 100 --ipconfig0 ip=dhcp
Note: IP configuration changes require the QEMU guest agent to be installed and running in the VM. The changes will be applied the next time the VM boots.

Applying IP Changes to a Running VM

After changing the IP configuration, you need to reboot the VM to apply the changes:

# Reboot the VM to apply changes
qm reboot <vmid>

# Example for VM with ID 100
qm reboot 100

Verifying IP Configuration Changes

After the VM reboots, you can verify the new IP configuration:

# Check VM configuration
qm config <vmid>

# Check network interfaces via guest agent
qm agent <vmid> network-get-interfaces

Container IP Address Management

Reading Container Configuration

To view the complete configuration of a container, use the pct config command:

# Show container configuration
pct config <ctid>

# Example for container with ID 100
pct config 100

Example output:

arch: amd64
cores: 1
hostname: container1
memory: 512
net0: name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.101/24,gw=192.168.1.1
rootfs: local-lvm:vm-100-disk-0,size=8G

Modifying Container IP Address

To change the IP address of an existing container:

# Change to static IP
pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Example for container with ID 101
pct set 101 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=192.168.1.102/24,gw=192.168.1.1

Setting DHCP for a Container

To configure a container to use DHCP instead of a static IP:

# Change to DHCP
pct set <ctid> --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp

# Example for container with ID 100
pct set 100 --net0 name=eth0,bridge=vmbr0,ip=dhcp

Applying IP Changes to a Container

After changing the IP configuration, you need to restart the container to apply the changes:

# Apply changes by restarting the container
pct restart <ctid>

# Example for container with ID 101
pct restart 101

Verifying Container IP Configuration

After the container restarts, you can verify the new IP configuration:

# Check container configuration
pct config <ctid>

# Enter the container to check network configuration
pct enter <ctid>

# Inside the container, check IP configuration
ip addr show

Advanced IP Configuration

Adding Multiple Network Interfaces

For VMs with multiple network interfaces:

# Add a second network interface to a VM
qm set <vmid> --net1 virtio,bridge=vmbr0

# Configure IP for the second interface
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig1 ip=10.10.10.100/24

For containers with multiple network interfaces:

# Add a second network interface to a container
pct set <ctid> --net1 name=eth1,bridge=vmbr1,ip=10.10.10.101/24

# Add a third network interface without IP (to be configured inside the container)
pct set <ctid> --net2 name=eth2,bridge=vmbr0,ip=manual

Using Cloud-Init for VM IP Configuration

For VMs created from Cloud-Init templates, you can set the IP address using Cloud-Init:

# Set Cloud-Init IP configuration
qm set <vmid> --ipconfig0 ip=192.168.1.100/24,gw=192.168.1.1

# Set Cloud-Init DNS servers
qm set <vmid> --nameserver 8.8.8.8

# Set Cloud-Init search domain
qm set <vmid> --searchdomain example.com

Troubleshooting IP Configuration

Common Issues and Solutions

VM IP Configuration Not Applied

  • Ensure the QEMU guest agent is installed and running in the VM
  • Verify the VM has been rebooted after configuration changes
  • Check that the network interface exists in the VM
# Check if guest agent is enabled in VM configuration
qm config <vmid> | grep agent

# Enable guest agent if not already enabled
qm set <vmid> --agent enabled=1

# Inside the VM (for Debian/Ubuntu)
apt update
apt install qemu-guest-agent
systemctl enable qemu-guest-agent
systemctl start qemu-guest-agent

Container IP Configuration Not Applied

  • Ensure the container has been restarted after configuration changes
  • Verify the network interface exists in the container
  • Check that the bridge interface exists on the host
# Check bridge interfaces on the host
ip addr show | grep vmbr

# Check container network configuration
pct config <ctid> | grep net

# Restart container to apply changes
pct restart <ctid>

content.text:
I've made the following changes to ensure the Proxmox commands documentation is properly accessible:

1. Updated the ScanMethods.pm file to properly categorize files in the proxmox directory:
   - Added a specific condition to detect files in the Documentation/proxmox/ directory
   - Ensured these files are added to the proxmox category

2. Updated the links in the documentation templates:
   - Changed the link in the quick access section of index.tt from `/Documentation/proxmox_commands.tt` to `/Documentation/proxmox/commands`
   - Changed the link in the featured section of proxmox.tt from `/Documentation/proxmox_commands.tt` to `/Documentation/proxmox/commands`
   - Updated the FOREACH loop in proxmox.tt to exclude 'commands' instead of 'proxmox_commands'

These changes ensure that:
1. The commands.tt file in the proxmox directory is properly categorized
2. The file is accessible through the documentation system
3. Links to the file are correct and working

Now users will be able to find and access the Proxmox commands documentation through:
- The quick access links for administrators on the documentation index page
- The featured documentation in the Proxmox documentation section
- The general documentation listing if they have admin privileges

The documentation is now properly integrated into the system and accessible through the browser interface.
